questions.article: Possessing an outstanding collection of public art, Chicago has everything from monumental sculptures like Pablo Picasso's Chicago Picasso at sites like Daley Plaza to innovative street art like Justus Roe's mural Standing Wave located on South State Street. The ______ public art on display in the city can thus satisfy any art lover.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: controversy over

options.name: B
options.content: breadth of

options.name: C
options.content: apathy toward

options.name: D
options.content: confusion about

questions.correct: breadth of

questions.article: In a 2018 article about films depicting the experiences of Black Americans, critics for the New York Times praise Carl Franklin's 1995 film Devil in a Blue Dress as "picture-perfect" and Cheryl Dunye's 1996 film The Watermelon Woman as "heartbreaking and inspiring." Fans of the two films hope that such ______ will attract new audiences to these works.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: acclaim

options.name: B
options.content: ambivalence

options.name: C
options.content: foresight

options.name: D
options.content: impartiality

questions.correct: acclaim

questions.article: The fossil remains of the individual known as Misliya-1, discovered in Israel in 2002, can help paleoanthropologists not only ______ steps in the evolution of hominids but also illuminate the Pleistocene epoch generally, revealing important details about the time in which Misliya-1 lived.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: yield

options.name: B
options.content: discern

options.name: C
options.content: prioritize

options.name: D
options.content: exploit

questions.correct: discern

questions.article: Though few critics consider Vasily Grossman's novel Stalingrad—which focuses on the experience of the Soviet Union in the early years of World War II—to be as well written as his later book Everything Flows, some compliment it despite the damage ______ Soviet censors: Gary Saul Morson in The New York Review of Books called the novel "remarkably bold."
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: bestowed on

options.name: B
options.content: wrought by

options.name: C
options.content: allocated to

options.name: D
options.content: concealed from

questions.correct: wrought by

questions.article: Archaeologists studying the ancient city of Pompeii in Italy recently discovered a well-preserved food shop known as a thermopolium. The site contains food remains, artworks, and decorations. These items give researchers a better understanding of what daily life in Pompeii may have been like. For example, the archaeologists found a ceramic jar that they believe likely contained a meat and seafood stew.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To discuss the political system of Italy

options.name: B
options.content: To present a recent archaeological discovery

options.name: C
options.content: To describe a region's climate

options.name: D
options.content: To compare ancient artworks with modern ones

questions.correct: To present a recent archaeological discovery

questions.article:
Text 1
In separate studies, Joanna Weremijewicz and colleagues and Xinhua He and colleagues examined whether plants transfer nutrients to one another using a common mycorrhizal in the soil. Weremijewicz and colleagues excluded all pathways other than the CMN by using barriers to keep the plants' root systems separate while allowing mycorrhizal strands through—a crucial step He and colleagues' study did not take.

Text 2
Weremijewicz and colleagues took the necessary precaution of separating the plants root systems (thereby excluding root-to-root transmission). However, any barrier used must allow the thread-like hyphae of a CMN to pass through, and this permeability would also allow liquids through. Thus, the researchers experimental design cannot ensure that any nutrient transfer observed can be attributed to a CMN and not to some other pathway.
questions.question: Based on the texts, the author of Text 1 and the author of Text 2 would most likely agree on which point?

options.name: A
options.content: Excluding root-to-root transfer of nutrients between plants is sufficient to ensure that any observed nutrient transfer must involve a CMN.

options.name: B
options.content: A barrier that is impervious to both roots and fungal strands is necessary to evaluate nutrient transfer via a CMN.

options.name: C
options.content: He and colleagues' study did not find convincing evidence of nutrient transfer between individual plants.

options.name: D
options.content: The barriers used in Weremijewicz and colleagues' study effectively excluded root-to-root transmission of nutrients.

questions.correct: The barriers used in Weremijewicz and colleagues' study effectively excluded root-to-root transmission of nutrients.

questions.article:
Text 1

For thousands of years, O'odham farmers in the Sonoran desert of the southwestern US and northern Mexico have cultivated organ pipe fruit and beans, sometimes planting these species together so that the organ pipe cacti provide shade for tepary beans. Doing so helps protect tepary beans from the harshest heat and light and thereby helps prevent soil moisture from evaporating.

Text 2

Tepary beans are well adapted to growing in the desert but grow best when shaded. Inspired by O'odham farmers, who often strategically plant tepary beans in the shade of sun hardy species like organ pipe cacti for protection from the sun and heat, Gary Nabhan and colleagues planted tepary beans in the shade of solar panels in the Sonoran desert and found that the plants grew well, suggesting to Nabhan and colleagues that the panels provide a benefit similar to that provided by organ pipe cacti.
questions.question: Based on the texts, the author of Text 1 and the author of Text 2 would most likely agree on which point?

options.name: A
options.content: Compared with Nabhan's approach, the O'odham approach has the advantage of producing beans.

options.name: B
options.content: Nabhan's team's method could be refined to more actively prevent soil moisture from evaporating.

options.name: C
options.content: Organ pipe cacti can provide shade that protects tepary beans from high-intensity heat and light.

options.name: D
options.content: Organ pipe cacti grow best when planted in shaded areas, while tepary beans do not require shade to thrive.

questions.correct: Organ pipe cacti can provide shade that protects tepary beans from high-intensity heat and light.

questions.article: Optimal foraging theory (OFT) holds that animals' foraging behaviors reflect cost-benefit trade-offs that vary by species and with dynamic ecologic circumstances. One such circumstance is lunar intensity, which Nathan Upham and John Hafner found to be negatively associated with foraging by desert kangaroo rats but Ian C. Colquhoun found to be positively associated with foraging by black lemurs. This discrepancy is explicable in terms of OFT: the lemurs' greater reliance on vision means that higher lunar intensity benefits them more than it benefits the kangaroo rats.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the finding made by Colquhoun, as presented in the text?

options.name: A
options.content: As lunar intensity increases, black lemurs increase their foraging activity.

options.name: B
options.content: Increased lunar intensity is more beneficial for black lemurs than it is for desert kangaroo rats.

options.name: C
options.content: As lunar intensity increases, desert kangaroo rats reduce their foraging activity.

options.name: D
options.content: During periods of high lunar intensity, black lemurs increase their reliance on vision.

questions.correct: As lunar intensity increases, black lemurs increase their foraging activity.

questions.article: The bird species Cercomacra cinerascens (the gray antbird) shares some territory in French Guiana with Thamnomanes caesius (the cinereous antshrike), which emits a loud alarm call when it detects predators. Biologist Ari Martinez and colleagues recorded T. caesius alarm calls and played them in the vicinity of wild C. cinerascens. Finding that the birds often froze in place or scattered into vegetation upon hearing the calls, they concluded that C. cinerascens associates T. caesius alarm calls with danger.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support Martinez and colleagues' conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: Martinez and colleagues played alarm calls from different T. caesius individuals and observed no significant variation in the responses of C. cinerascens.

options.name: B
options.content: When Martinez and colleagues played control sounds of random noise in the vicinity of C. cinerascens, the birds displayed no reaction.

options.name: C
options.content: In some instances C. cinerascens froze in place or scattered into vegetation when Martinez and colleagues approached but before they began playing sounds.

options.name: D
options.content: Other bird species than C. cinerascens also showed a tendency to freeze in place or scatter into vegetation when Martinez and colleagues played T. caesius alarm calls.

questions.correct: When Martinez and colleagues played control sounds of random noise in the vicinity of C. cinerascens, the birds displayed no reaction.

questions.article: The Underdogs is a 1915 novel by Mariano Azuela, originally written in Spanish. In the novel, Azuela makes a comparison using natural imagery to convey the mental state of the protagonist, Demetrio: ______
questions.question: Which quotation from a translation of The Underdogs most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: "The river crept along, murmuring as the waters rose and fell in small cascades."

options.name: B
options.content: "Demetrio suppressed a sigh. Memories crowded and buzzed through his brain like bees about a hive."

options.name: C
options.content: "When he reached the summit, he glanced down to see the sun steeping the valley in a lake of gold."

options.name: D
options.content: "Demetrio laid a hand on his hair which covered his ears, and stretching himself out for a longtime, seemed to be lost in thought."

questions.correct: "Demetrio suppressed a sigh. Memories crowded and buzzed through his brain like bees about a hive."

questions.article: It is common for freshwater lakes near or above a latitude of 45° north of the equator, like Lake Stechlin in Germany, to accumulate surface ice in winter. A study from 1980 to 2006 showed that, in general, the number of days per winter that such lakes have measurable amounts of surface ice is declining. However, a researcher claimed that some lakes have instead seen an increase in the duration of ice, citing as an example ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the graph to complete the researcher's example?

options.name: A
options.content: both Lake Baikal and Oulujarvi, which had more than 100 days of ice in the winter of 2005-06.

options.name: B
options.content: both Lake Baikal and Oulujarvi, which had fewer than 195 days of ice in the winter of 1980-81.

options.name: C
options.content: Lake Baikal, which had more days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than it did in the winter of 1980-81.

options.name: D
options.content: both Lake Kegonsa and Oulujarvi, which had more days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than they did in the winter of 1980-81.

questions.correct: Lake Baikal, which had more days of ice in the winter of 2005-06 than it did in the winter of 1980-81.

questions.article: The linguistic niche hypothesis (LNH) posits that the exotericity of languages (how prevalent non-native speakers are) and grammatical complexity are inversely related, which the LNH ascribes to attrition of complex grammatical rules as more non-native speakers adopt the language but fail to acquire those rules. Focusing on two characteristics that are positive indices of grammatical complexity, fusion (when new phonemes arise from the merger of previously distinct ones) and informativity (languages' capacity for meaningful variation), Olena Shcherbakova and colleagues conducted a quantitative analysis for more than 1,300 languages and claim the outcome is inconsistent with the LNH.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support Shcherbakova and colleagues' claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Shcherbakova and colleagues' analysis showed a slightly positive correlation between grammatical complexity and fusion.

options.name: B
options.content: Shcherbakova and colleagues' analysis showed a slightly negative correlation between grammatical complexity and exotericity.

options.name: C
options.content: Shcherbakova and colleagues' analysis showed a slightly positive correlation between fusion and exotericity and between informativity and exotericity.

options.name: D
options.content: Shcherbakova and colleagues' analysis showed a slightly negative correlation between grammatical complexity and fusion and between grammatical complexity and informativity.

questions.correct: Shcherbakova and colleagues' analysis showed a slightly positive correlation between fusion and exotericity and between informativity and exotericity.

questions.article: Neuroscientist Kiyohito Ligaya and colleagues developed a computational model to predict how much a person will enjoy a particular work of art on a scale from 1 (not at all) to 4 (very much). They then recruited participants to use the same scale to rate several sets of paintings in various styles and calculated the correlation between the ratings predicted by the model and those reported by the participants. Assuming participant P6 gave equal ratings to the abstract and cubist paintings, the data in the graph indicate the model predicted that ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the graph to complete the example?

options.name: A
options.content: P6's ratings for abstract and cubist paintings would differ from one another.

options.name: B
options.content: P6 would derive less aesthetic pleasure from abstract paintings than from cubist paintings.

options.name: C
options.content: P6's rating for abstract and cubist paintings would equal one another.

options.name: D
options.content: P6 would derive more aesthetic pleasure from abstract paintings than from cubist paintings.

questions.correct: P6's ratings for abstract and cubist paintings would differ from one another.

questions.article: Arthurian legends (tales related to the character of King Arthur) derive from many often contradictory sources, such as Y Goroddin, composed between the 7th and 11th centuries and the Mabinogion from the 12th and 13th centuries. Sir Thomas Malory's 15th-century text Le Morte d'Arthur was an attempt to compile these stories into a coherent narrative. Many of Malory's sources derive from Geoffrey of Monmouth's History of the Kings of Britain, written in the 1130s. While neither History nor any works that predate it mention Arthur's famous Round Table at which his knights assembled, Le Morte d'Arthur does, suggesting that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Le Morte d'Arthur is more historically accurate than History because the Mabinogion had not been written when Geoffrey of Monmouth was writing his work.

options.name: B
options.content: when a version of an Arthurian legend contradicted the version in History, Malory preferred to include Geoffrey of Monmouth's version in Le Morte d'Arthur.

options.name: C
options.content: Malory encountered the Round Table in a source that Geoffrey of Monmouth was not familiar with when writing his History.

options.name: D
options.content: Geoffrey of Monmouth's accounts of Arthurian legends in History are more similar overall in content to the accounts in the Mabinogion than they are to the accounts in Le Morte d'Arthur.

questions.correct: Malory encountered the Round Table in a source that Geoffrey of Monmouth was not familiar with when writing his History.

questions.article: Prolonged exposure to anthropogenic noise (sounds from human sources like traffic or mining) can affect animals, as Erin P. Walsh and colleagues found in a 2017 study of hermit crabs. Researchers conducted a meta-analysis of studies of how such noise affects animals and found that, for every study, relevant traits or behaviors of the animals were observably different between the exposed group and the otherwise similar but unexposed group. Although, on average, studies of arthropods showed larger differences than studies of birds did, for every class of animals examined, there were individual studies showing differences well above the average for arthropods. Therefore, the results of the meta-analysis suggest that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: the studies in the meta analysis that examined arthropods were more likely than those that examined birds to specify whether the observed effects were detrimental.

options.name: B
options.content: the difference found in the study conducted by Erin P Walsh and colleagues was likely larger than the average difference for studies of hermit crabs included in the meta-analysis.

options.name: C
options.content: some studies of birds found larger effects of exposure to anthropogenic noise than some studies of arthropods did.

options.name: D
options.content: the differences that studies attribute to exposure to anthropogenic noise are likely to be more pronounced for birds than they are for arthropods.

questions.correct: some studies of birds found larger effects of exposure to anthropogenic noise than some studies of arthropods did.

questions.article: The term "retroflex" derives from Latin and means "bent back," an apt description for the branch of consonants—retroflex consonants—pronounced with the tongue curling up and back in the mouth. In many languages, including English, these consonants are ______ in some dialects of Mandarin, however, four such consonants ("ch," "sh," "zh," and "r") are relatively common.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: rare and

options.name: B
options.content: rare;

options.name: C
options.content: rare

options.name: D
options.content: rare,

questions.correct: rare;

questions.article: Along with carbon dioxide concentration and temperature, light intensity affects the chemical reaction rate of ______ as light intensity increases, so does the rate at which the reactants (water and carbon dioxide) are converted into their products (glucose and oxygen).
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: photosynthesis:

options.name: B
options.content: photosynthesis,

options.name: C
options.content: photosynthesis

options.name: D
options.content: photosynthesis and

questions.correct: photosynthesis:

questions.article: The fungus Tricholoma matsutake, commonly referred to as matsutake, is known to establish ectomycorrhizal bonds with certain pine tree species; in many cases, such symbiotic relationships, wherein fungal hyphae make contact with the pine's root system, ______ extensive networks, which can be used to transport nutrients between trees.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: having formed

options.name: B
options.content: form

options.name: C
options.content: to form

options.name: D
options.content: forming

questions.correct: form

questions.article: Though he would go on to work with many respected bands, including John McLaughlin and the Free Spirits on their album Tokyo Lie, American ______ may be best known for his time with Sugar Hill Records, where he helped craft the sound of early hip-hop music.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: drummer Dennis Chambers,

options.name: B
options.content: drummer Dennis Chambers

options.name: C
options.content: drummer, Dennis Chambers,

options.name: D
options.content: drummer, Dennis Chambers

questions.correct: drummer Dennis Chambers

questions.article: In his painting At the Cycle Race Track, Jean Metzinger aims to depict a bike race in four-dimensional space. Of course, Metzinger's painting doesn't technically represent a fourth dimension, humans can only see in three dimensions. ______ by depicting the race through multiple, simultaneous perspectives, Metzinger offers a fascinating glimpse at what this other universe might look like.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: For example,

options.name: B
options.content: In other words,

options.name: C
options.content: Moreover,

options.name: D
options.content: That said,

questions.correct: That said,

questions.article: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) tracks comparative price list data for its thirty-eight member countries. According to this data, in July 2021, a "basket" of goods and services priced at 100 US dollars (USD) in the United States would have cost 59 USD in fellow OECD member ______
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: nation, Lithuania.

options.name: B
options.content: nation; Lithuania.

options.name: C
options.content: nation—Lithuania.

options.name: D
options.content: nation Lithuania.

questions.correct: nation Lithuania.

questions.article: If you could travel in a spaceship to Elara, one of Jupiter's many moons, you'd find a moon with a prograde orbit. This means that Elara orbits Jupiter in the same direction that Jupiter rotates on its axis. ______ at Harpalyke, another Jovian moon, you'd find an example of a retrograde orbit, with the moon revolving around Jupiter in the opposite direction.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Specifically,

options.name: B
options.content: In other words,

options.name: C
options.content: For example,

options.name: D
options.content: Elsewhere,

questions.correct: Elsewhere,

questions.article: In 2015, geologist Peter Rogerson recalculated the geographic center of Illinois, which had previously been determined in 1920 by the US Geological Survey (USGS). The USGS, Rogerson contended, had omitted important considerations, not least the curvature of the earth. ______ the state's USGS-determined center--a point 1.5 miles southeast of the municipality of Rochester--was inaccurate.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: However,

options.name: B
options.content: That being said,

options.name: C
options.content: Hence,

options.name: D
options.content: Next,

questions.correct: Hence,

questions.article: On June 20, 1932, aviator Amelia Earhart received a ticker-tape parade in New York City in recognition of her transatlantic flight. Of the 206 ticker-tape parades held between 1886 and 2022, a number were for achievements in aviation. ______ Earhart's parade was just one of 16 honoring pilots.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: In addition,

options.name: B
options.content: Indeed,

options.name: C
options.content: Nevertheless,

options.name: D
options.content: Therefore,

questions.correct: Indeed,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Bauhaus was an influential German art and design school founded in 1919 by Walter Gropius.
  • Gropius was the school's director from 1919 to 1928.
  • Hannes Meyer was its director from 1928 to 1930.
  • Ludwig Mies van der Rohe was its director from 1930 to 1933.
  • Benita Koch-Otte was a textile artist who began attending the Bauhaus in 1920.
  • Grete Stern was a photographer who began attending the Bauhaus in 1930.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize the order in which the two students attended the Bauhaus. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Founded in 1919, the Bauhaus was a German art and design school whose past students include Benita Koch-Otte and Grete Stern.

options.name: B
options.content: Walter Gropius founded the Bauhaus in 1919 and acted as its director until 1928, at which point Hannes Meyer succeeded him in the role.

options.name: C
options.content: Benita Koch-Otte and Grete Stern were both Bauhaus students, but Koch-Otte, who began attending in 1920, preceded Stern.

options.name: D
options.content: The Bauhaus was founded in 1919, and Grete Stern began attending in 1930.

questions.correct: Benita Koch-Otte and Grete Stern were both Bauhaus students, but Koch-Otte, who began attending in 1920, preceded Stern.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Generally an object will heat up when twisted.
  • The twisting of an object is known as torsion.
  • A 2019 study led by Zunfeng Liu and Kay Baughman tested the torsional heating of various fibers.
  • When a 0.7 millimeter thick sample of single ply nickel titanium (NiTi) wire was twisted, its average surface temperature increased by 21.3°C.
  • When a 2.2 millimeter thick sample of natural rubber fiber was twisted, its average surface temperature increased by 15.3°C.
questions.question: The student wants to contrast the two samples. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The natural rubber sample used in the 2019 study was thicker than the single ply NiTi wire sample.

options.name: B
options.content: In 2019, researchers studied the effect of torsional heating on various fibers, including samples of natural rubber and single ply NiTi wire.

options.name: C
options.content: When the fibers were twisted as part of the 2019 study, the surface temperature of both samples increased.

options.name: D
options.content: Twisting an object will generally cause its temperature to increase, a process known as torsional heating.

questions.correct: The natural rubber sample used in the 2019 study was thicker than the single ply NiTi wire sample.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Element abundance is a relative measure of the amount of a chemical element in a given environment.
  • Abundance can be expressed as a mass fraction.
  • A mass fraction is the ratio of the total mass of an element to the combined mass of all elements in a given environment.
  • The mass fraction of oxygen (O) on Earth is 297,000 parts per million (ppm).
  • The mass fraction of vanadium (V) on Earth is 105 ppm.
questions.question: The student wants to specify the total mass of Earth's oxygen relative to that of all elements. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Oxygen's abundance on Earth is greater than vanadium's, as reflected by oxygen's higher mass fraction.

options.name: B
options.content: Oxygen's abundance can be expressed by a mass fraction, a measure of the element's mass relative to that of all elements on Earth.

options.name: C
options.content: The mass fraction of oxygen on Earth is 297,000 ppm.

options.name: D
options.content: Oxygen's mass relative to the combined mass of all elements on Earth is 105 ppm.

questions.correct: The mass fraction of oxygen on Earth is 297,000 ppm.
